look what i ran into today! a newer version but with a double shell, and for gyroscope instead of CSAC. the fabrication process is also wild, wafer cavity etch -> triple wafer bonding -> annealing/micro glassblowing -> back-lapping the substrate away -> bond again. this one has electrostatic actuation & readout, an even newer version has optical readout. Hemispherical resonator gyroscope (HRG)

the array of electrodes can selectively excite different modes based on how they are configured. - Asadian2022: [Fused Quartz Dual-Shell Resonator Gyroscope]( https://doi.org/10.1109/JMEMS.2022.3166213)
Q of 1~2 million at ~5 kHz, Allan deviation of 0.058 deg/√hr, and "in-run bias instability of 0.4 deg/hr without temperature control"
all hail COMSOL! glassblowing shape prediction? no problem! and the final mesh from the fluid flow sim could go straight to mechanical eigen mode sim.

if you are into HRGs in general, this review from northrop grumman has a lot of nice low res pictures.. - Rozelle2009: [The Hemispherical Resonator Gyro: From Wineglass to the Planets]( https://www.researchgate.net/profile/David-Rozelle/publication/279909300_The_Hemispherical_Resonator_Gyro_From_Wineglass_to_the_Planets/links/00b7d53bd65d3c57b4000000/The-Hemispherical-Resonator-Gyro-From-Wineglass-to-the-Planets.pdf)
look at this magnificent piece of chip

- Wang2022: [Effect of Metallization on Quality Factor and Noise Characteristics in Fused Silica Dual-Shell Gyroscopes]( https://doi.org/10.1109/JMEMS.) - [also]( https://researchgate.net/profile/Danmen)

you have to bake it for 120 h lol - Cooper2021: [Additively manufactured ultra-high vacuum chamber for portable quantum technologies]( https://doi.org/10.1016/j.addma.2021.101898)

most of our technology really hasn't moved that further away from your daily intuition, in the sense that if you've experienced the anti-splash urinal screen mats, you pretty much get how a broad range of broadband anti-reflection materials work, and even this 3D printed surface for better passive pumping. (well the Q-switched laser pulse being a toilet flush might be stretching it)
this shape is really the best shape. - Cooper2026: [Exploiting complex 3D-printed surface structures for portable quantum technologies]( https://doi.org/10.1103/rg8y-rpsc)

let's try to guestimate the film thickness and uniformity here and see if grok actually guessed it right. As you'd expect, the perceived color looks amazingly similar across many single layer thin films. ( left image made by claude and right image from [this tweet]( https://x.com/jwt0625/status/1994498739441209642) )

first is to figure out the stack. From the tweet as well as [this paper]( https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-025-08820-7), we know it is MBE, and the thickness should be around 135 nm. there may be a STO buffer layer for the MBE [Mazet2015]( https://doi.org/10.1088/1468-6996/16/3/036005), but it would be thin (few 10s of nm), and close in refractive index, so we are gonna ignore it.

next is to get the reflection response of the stack, which is pretty simple from transfer matrix method. You can ask claude to do it in 2 min. The reflection depends on angle and polarization, and measuring the change in polarization components' relative amplitude and phase is actually a very robust measurement for film thickness and/or refractive index. One company making such equipment is J.A. Woollam, and they have a nice series of tutorials on how it works (and even a book iirc) - [J.A. Woollam - Ellipsometry Tutorial]( https://www.jawoollam.com/resources/ellipsometry-tutorial) I've spent countless sessions on such tool measuring TFLN thickness taht I could probably yap for a while on its calibration, fit recipes, optimizing the incident angles, optical anisotropy and Euler angles of your model etc. Also the software/GUI sucks.

here are the results from claude, it picked Sellmeier equation to model the wavelength dependency of BTO's refractive index even without explicit ask (good bot), and I asked it to calculate both the ellipsometry results (left, should look very familiar to you if you've done it), as well as the reflection spectrum (right). The ellipsometry angles are chosen to be around the brewster angles because you'll see it blow up and be sensitive to film thickness. The reflectance is calculated near the actual angle where the photo was taken from the aspect ratio of the wafer.

next, we need some assumptions on the light source and the camera. I have no idea on them so claude made the call of using D65 Standard Illuminant and sRGB and CIE 1931 2° Standard Observer. I have no idea what these means. But anyway now you get color vs thickness vs angle.
correction: it's more like 53.5 deg. it's also tricky to get rid of the glare..
guess you really need a good model for the source and the glare to make these results more trustworthy.

hmm cool quasi zero stiffness device by combining a v-shaped bistable beam (VBB) and a diamond-shape mechanism (DSM), so the force displacement curve slope adds up to near zero. 3d printable too. - Li2024: [Design and characterization of a compact tripod quasi-zero-stiffness device for isolating low-frequency vibrations]( https://doi.org/10.1016/j.precisioneng.2024.10.013)
damn it looks good
nice! hmm how do that two cross-beam like shapes get negative slope, do they buckle?

100,000 dipole antennas over 200 square km to the moon (it's actually going to be from the moon) - [The Quest to Build a Radio Telescope That Can Hear the Cosmic Dark Ages]( https://spectrum.ieee.org/lunar-radio-te)

a few required tech for in situ resource utilization (ISRU): - Molten Regolith Electrolysis (MRE): predicted TRL-5 by mid-2024, TRL-6 by 2025, no public TRL-6 yet - Space Deposition System (SDS): TRL-6 before a planned 2025 spaceflight demo, no flight demo yet - Pulsed Electrical Discharge additive manufacturing (PE3D): TRL-3~5, TRL-6 within 2 years, deployment of prototypes to the lunar surface by 2028 - Polidan2024: [FarView: An in-situ manufactured lunar far side radio array concept for 21-cm Dark Ages cosmology]( https://doi.org/10.1016/j.asr.2024.04.008)
theres a cool unlisted video about it - [FarView Radio Observatory]( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FOUAMRyttPU)

i have to constantly update my perception on what is possible with TPP/TPA. Nonlinearity is weird, and you have both optical and chemical nonlinearity, and amazing things happen when your pulse gets shorter and shorter. This is with a green fs laser at 517 nm.

they call it few-photon irradiated TPA (fpTPA), where a single pulse only has 1000~2000 photons. still not intuitive to me why the radial density of possible TPA events drop this fast from monte carlo.. it gets more stochastic as the pulse gets weaker, so you could use multiple pulses / exposures to improve the contrast. - Liang2025: [Two-photon absorption under few-photon irradiation for optical nanoprinting]( https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-025-57390-9)
hmm good point, these are all classical "boring" photons. Maybe you'll get a sqrt(N) boost like SQL, then not worth it if it's a two photon process
true, OPA/OPO underrated
